title: This week: Events for Oct. 11
text:
S

CIRCUS 
The Zoppé
Family Circus 
Performing in the Old World Italian tradition, this unique one-ring circus tells a story, in which the individual acts participate. In addition to its star, Nino the clown, you’ll see acrobatics, canine capers, equestrian showmanship and more. Nino loves audience participation. Noon, 4 and 6 p.m. Sunday (Oct. 11); 6:30 p.m. Tuesday-Thursday; 4 and 7 p.m. Friday; noon, 4 and 7 p.m. Saturday. Through Oct. 25. Circus Tent: 1455 Madison Ave. , Red Morton Park, Redwood City. $12-$26. (650) 780-7586, redwoodcity.org/events/zoppe.html.
ART 
Dance Party 
A visual interpretation of today’s dance culture portrays the vibrancy of dance as the social activity and communal activity that we see on TV, YouTube, in the movies and in many other places. The exhibition features paintings, drawings, video and installation art. Noon-5 p.m. Sunday (Oct. 11); 10 a.m.-3 p.m. Monday-Wednesday and Friday; 10 a.m.-7 p.m. Thursday; noon-5 p.m. Saturday. Through Nov. 22. Creativity Explored Gallery, 3245 16th St., San Francisco. Free. (415) 863-2108, www.creativityexplored.org. 
M
LECTURE 
Chef Jacques Pépin
This celebrated French chef memorably co-starred with renowned chef Julia Child on the Emmy Award-winning PBS show “Julia and Jacques Cooking at Home.” He also was the personal chef to three French heads of state. Pépin talks on stage with fellow chef and TV host Tyler Florence of Mill Valley. 7 p.m. Monday. Angelico Hall , Dominican University, Acacia and Grand avenues, San Rafael. (415) 927-0960, www.bookpassage.com. 
T
LECTURE 
Karen Armstrong 
The former Roman Catholic nun is a well-known commentator on religion. She draws from Judaism, Christianity and Islam. Her books include “Muhammad, A History of God,” “The Great Transformation,” and “Through the Narrow Gate.” Her forthcoming book is a sweeping look at religion’s connection to violence. Armstrong converses with Jane Shaw , dean for religious life at Stanford University and minister of Memorial Church. 7:30 p.m. Tuesday. The Nourse, 275 Hayes St., San Francisco. $29. (415) 392-4400, www.cityboxoffice.com. 
W
MUSIC 
Berkeley Symphony
The Berkeley Symphony opens its season with Kaiija Saariaho’s “Laterna Magica.” The name alludes to the autobiography of the same name by Swedish film director Ingmar Bergman . Commissioned by the Berlin Philharmonic in 2009, Saariaho’s work moves through musical motifs and tempi. The program also features Canadian soprano Simone Osborne singing Berlioz’s song cycle, “Les nuits de’ete.” Ravel’s “Bolero” also is performed. 7 p.m. Wednesday. Zellerbach Hall, UC Berkeley. $15-$74. (510) 841-2800, www.berkeleysymphony.org. 

T
THEATER 
‘The Odd Couple’
Neil Simon ’s award-winning play is a classic. Nothing but trouble and hilarity ensue when slovenly sportswriter Oscar Madison and persnickety Felix Ungar move in together after their wives throw them out. Yet, the roommates learn valuable lessons about the meaning of life, love and friendship. Thursday-Saturday; 2 p.m. next Sunday. Through Nov. 1. Hillbarn Theatre , 1285 East Hillsdale Blvd., Foster City. $25-$48 (650) 349-6411, www.hillbarntheatre.org. 
F
EXPOSITION 
Grand National Rodeo
There’s nothing like a good old-fashioned rodeo. This year’s featured performance is Bobby Kerr ’s Professional Mustang Specialty Act. Kerr is the founder of the Texas Cowboy Hall of Fame. The show includes roping, bucking broncos, the Arabian Costume Class performance, a livestock exposition, horse shows, barbecues and dancing. 7:30 p.m. Friday-Sat. Through Oct. 24. Cow Palace, 2600 Geneva Ave., Daly City. $38-$120. (866) 448-7849, www.ticketmaster.com. 
S
DANCE
‘Kanakolu —
30 Years of Hula’
It’s the 30th anniversary of Kumu Hula Patrick Makuakane’s award-winning dance troupe, Na Lei Hulu I Ka Wekiu. The company celebrates its body of work with “Kanakolu — 30 Years of Hula,” a retrospective that includes its trademark hula mua, a method of bringing ancient Hawaiian dance into the modern world. The result is culturally and visually rich. 8 p.m. Saturday; 3 p.m. next Sunday. Through Oct. 25. Palace of Fine Arts , 3301 Lyon St., San Francisco. $10-$40. (415) 392-4400, www.cityboxoffice.com. 
PERFORMANCE 
‘The Town
on Notice’
Dimensions Dance Theater presents a lively show that takes on the subject of Oakland’s gentrification. The Bay Area’s pre-eminent African American dance company combines dance, live music, spoken work and stand-up comedy as an invitation for the audience to interact and engage in meaningful dialogue. Featured performers include Korean-born composer JooWan Kim , poet Marvin K. White and comedian Micia Mosely. 8 p.m. Saturday. Malonga Casquelourd Center for the Arts, 1428 Alice St., Oakland. $25-$30. (800) 838-3006, www.brownpapertickets.com. 
— Kathleen Dixon
